Params[3]: Hey, Noan.
Did your dad leave?
Right.
Hey, look...
Huh?
Noan was about to tell Field what he'd just heard about Field's dad but decided to drop the topic.
What did the doctor say?
He said my immune system isn't working properly, which is why I come under the weather a lot more down here where it's wet and cold.
Boy, I can't wait for summer.
I won't be sick so often when summer is here... and Dad won't have to worry about me all the time.
Field rubs his fingers against the vial in his hand that comes with no label.
This medicine... costs us a fortune.
...Does your dad stay connected with Ashlar to keep his access to this medicine?
I have no idea... He refuses to tell me anything about it.
Do you like summer, Noan?
I don't have a favorite season because it doesn't really make a difference on the train.
But I guess I just might have one when I eventually get to go out with the Cargo Crew.
Cool. Say, why not let's go to the forest to look for fireflies in summer?
Fireflies? Why, though?
Because... they're beautiful? Have you seen one?
In the books I read, yes. And I've drawn some before.

Noan picks up a pencil and, on a makeshift sketchbook he's put together using scrap papers, draws a vertical line of circles. The circles seem like a cross between dandelions and the glowing balls that one would see reading mangas.
No, Noan. Fireflies don't actually look like this.
With his fingers, Field traces out a firefly.
A firefly has a pair of wings, and the only part of it that glows is its tummy.
We can try to look it up in the terminal, but I'm sure it wouldn't look as pretty in the pictures as if you see one in person.
Are there still any around?
Yes. My mom brought me to this place to see them before. We should do that, too.
Sounds great. I can go out there with the Cargo Crew after my training.
Noan looks up and stares at the dusty lights affixed to the car's ceiling.
Fireflies, eh...
I heard a lullaby before that has to do with fireflies.
A lullaby? Wait, do you mean this one?
Seeing Noan looking back at him with a bewildered look, Field hums out a part of what he believes is the lullaby Noan is talking about.
No, not this one.
Hmm...
Thinking for a few moments, Field hums out something different.
Yes, that's the one.
I see...
Deep in thought, they both fall silent.
Have you heard about how people think that grass turns into fireflies when it withers and decays?
Think I read about that somewhere, but that's just a superstition from the past, no?
Uhm, well...
My mom would always describe us as grass with our roots deep in the soil, but she never told me why she thought that...
But... I think I know why now.
Field runs his eyes through the words in the book again and again.

...We're as mundane as grass. See, this is what it says in the book. "Wild grass strikes no deep roots, has no beautiful flowers and leaves, yet it imbibes dew, water and the blood and flesh of the dead, all trying to rob them of life."
As long as it lives, it is trampled upon and mown down, until it dies and decays.
...But that doesn't mean wild grass is worthless.

You die because you lived, and you rot because you were. Dying weeds bear new lives, and while the skies might not be at their brightest now, the fire burning across the grassfield will light up the skies all the same.
It all makes sense, then, what people say about grass turning into fireflies when it withers and decays—because people can't stop missing something when it's gone, no matter how mundane it might be.
Field looks at Noan with a serious look on his face.

People tend to form their own imagination and association by reading books when they're still young—but it's entirely worth it if they can turn their imagination and association into "torches" that light up the path ahead for them.
...Why are you telling me these all of a sudden, though?
Well, because I was just reading this book, and because "goodbye" keeps coming up... in that lullaby you brought up.
So I thought of my mom—and how she might have turned into a firefly and might just be waiting for me out there in the forest to say "goodbye" to me.
Does it all sound like some fantasy I made up to make myself feel better?
No, it doesn't.
But, see, I was just thinking... that if people do turn into fireflies when they die, then we'd never have to say goodbye to them, right?
I'm just trapped in my memory and the night—and maybe I just need to bid farewell to myself.
Why would you have to do that, though?
...I'm responsible for my mom's death...

She'd always encourage me to read, but we didn't have a whole lot of books at home. The terminal at the pharmaceutical factory had a lot of electronic documents in it, so she'd take me there every so often at night when there wasn't anyone around.
And things went terribly wrong that night...
Field looks down in silence as he turns the pages in the book he's holding—and only opens his mouth to speak again after what seems like an eternity.
Since Mom died... there hasn't been a day where I didn't regret it...
And Dad has been living on the edge ever since to get me my medicine... all while I've been living in the melancholy of the past and been anything but helpful.
If I could just say goodbye to her in the forest where she died, would I be able to let it all go and have what it takes to carry on?
Noan shakes his head.
She made that choice to protect you—and I'm sure she'd never want you to forget about her, and I'm also sure she'd never want to see you crippled by regret.
...You're absolutely right, but I'm just too scared to face it. I can't do it.
I just can't be like you, Noan. You've lost so much coming so far, but you've never given up.
...Huh? What do you mean?
Noan doesn't understand those words—because he thinks he's learned things the hard way and already come to grips with reality.
Be it your memory or what you believe in, you hold on to them both.
You'd never have stood up for me or lent me a hand had you already given them up.
Field puts his now slightly cold hand on Noan's shoulder.
Deep down, you're deep into those heroic stories, aren't you?
...None of them is real, though.
That's only because you don't yet have the power to make them so, Noan, and not because you aren't determined enough.
What's the difference anyways?
Power corrupts you if power is all you have.
But you're different. You went out of your way to help me knowing full well you were no match for the guard... and that, Noan, is determination.
Determination, huh...
But I was this close to screwing everyone over back then, and Rachel asked me to swear that I'd never do it again... if I ever come across something like that.
Noan...
Field walks up to Noan and pats Noan's face.
...Yes?
C'mon, Noan...

I know you might be feeling guilty for putting everyone in harm's way, but nothing changes the fact that you saved me... and that's proof enough that you can still do what you want to do even when you don't yet have what it takes to make it perfect.
And I'll keep what you did for me in mind—and help people in need when I see them.
You might not be able to help everyone out there who's in need of help, but everyone you help will go on to help someone else. Sounds great, right?
Would you still do it if helping them means you're going to make everyone suffer?
Sure. I mean, kindness is a choice, and the world is to blame if it doesn't allow us to make that choice.
And that reminds me of what you said that day when you came up to help—"If you think I'm out of my mind for trying to help, then screw that!"
...Boy, you really need to forget that.
Uhm? Why, though?
...Wait, does it make you cringe?
Bingo? Oops.
Dude, just pretend I've never said any of that already...
Hah...
Ok, fine. I'll stop with that, but I'm never going to forget you helped me.
And, see, it's really got me thinking, and I think I'm going to help people however I can once my leg gets better.
...But you're already doing that, Field. You're helping me already.
Uhm? Am I?
You are. See...

Noan suddenly recalls all the things people have said about Field, and he can't help feeling tormented when he compares them with all the heart-warming encouragements he's heard from Field over the past few days.
Drawing a deep breath in hesitation, Noan decides to sweep it all under the carpet with thanks.
Thank you, Field. for telling me all this...
Not knowing why he's being thanked, the blonde boy lowers his head and laughs.
What do you want to be in the future, Noan?
...In the future?
Yeah. A dream, or a plan, or something. Something you want for yourself.
Noan closes his eyes in silence.
...Well...
He said something—but he just can't seem to recall the words that came out of his mouth.
How in the world did he even forget something so casual?
And you? What are you going to do?
I just want to get better—so I can leave the train and go to the forest to see all the fireflies, preferably with you and Dad.
But I'm nowhere close just yet, so I guess we'll just look forward to summer first.
...You really love summer, don't you?
With a burning passion, too, because it's only when summer is here that I don't get sick all the time.
It isn't exactly cold in the car, but Field just can't help looking forward to summer.
Summer is warm and all, but that's probably also when Field gets to relive in all his good memories without all the worries.
How would you like a new name for good luck?
Like what?
Field Lucifer Summer Hephaestus.
For the love of God...
Hugging himself, Field shivers from head to toe.
Oh, how about Field Seraph von Njord Und Frau des Feuers?
That's just a mix of everything!
Field raises his voice, something he rarely ever does.
Just call me Summer. Think that should give me enough good luck.
Alright, Summer it is, then.
Thanks!
I can totes add to it, though. Sure you're okay?
Thanks, but no thanks!
Two months go by.
Bancroft works day and night to make up for the lost goods—except there is no end to his team's blunders no matter how hard he works.
He manages to stay around with his connections to the aristocrats up there, but he's been finding it increasingly difficult to stay lately, with his team messing things up again and again.
Every so often, Noan would see Rachel give him a real piece of her mind in front of people.

Field has run out of his medicine, and the hellhole that's the lower level is eating away at his body, putting him through low fevers again and again—yet he'd always lie to his father when he checks on him.
When Noan trains, Field would stay in the book storage most of the time, where he would either be reading or napping in the corner.
Hey Summer, I'm back.
Hey. Did you see my dad tonight? He was supposed to be back for a few hours today...
I did, and he left after asking me a few questions about you.
Did he find the lost goods?
No, not yet.
What did Captain say?
...Welll...
I've personally busted some shitheads that tried to do their little things with the goods—and mind you, you're getting busted next if you pull another trick on me.
Please, Captain, I didn't do this!
Says the man who has a record of working for the aristocrats?
My son was in a very bad condition and he was the only one I could ask for help from!
You really gotta up your game, Bancroft.
...She pretty much said the same things she had before.
What did people say, though? Doesn't anyone have any idea who stole the goods?
...Well...
Bancroft, you said? Man, the man's a real thief and he's done it all... I want to be there to see him die the day he gets torn into pieces by Corrupted.
Better stay away from his son, boy! Young boy will probably grill you up when he gets hungry!
They don't seem like they want to help.
I'll definitely give your dad a hand when I finish my training in two months.
No, please don't, Noan... I think I know what my dad is up to, but I can't stop him.
He never passed the captain screening. He can work just fine as a crew member, but things are a disaster when he tries to play leader...
He needed help because I was injured... and he only found this place after pulling some strings. And, see, it wasn't resources that the aristocrats took from him in exchange... it was info.
I'm sure Dad would never have gone down this path had he still had resources to trade with the aristocrats... and I bet he wouldn't have had to go through any of these had I died back then.
You didn't ask to be roughed up, though—and I wouldn't have been the same without you, buddy...
People change, especially kids. Pretty sure our boy is gonna grow a whole lot more well-rounded the longer he hangs out with us.
Birds of a feather flock together, eh?
...Right, I really don't think I'd be the same person that I am today without you.
And did you forget about what you said about fireflies?
No, I do still remember what I said about fireflies—but I think I'm starting to have a change of mind now... knowing what happened to all those people my dad snitched on...
It's been six months since we boarded the train—and fox six whole months, that's how Dad got my medicine and the resources he had to pay for the lost goods.
And I'm just afraid that they're going to hurt someone close to you next—or maybe you, even...
C'mon, son... You hang around Rachel all the time now and she tells you everything, and you just never know what Bancroft is gonna do when he gets crazy somewhere down the road.
Look, son. Just do as we say... if you don't want what happened to your mom to happen to you.
And I don't see how that's any different from if we personally did the hurting ourselves.
It's fine, as long as your dad still gets paid properly for his work. He just needs to pay for the lost goods and make sure he never loses anything again.
But Dad just keeps losing them, and he hasn't even gotten what he's been working for because his pay all goes into paying for the goods lost.
And they still have no idea whatsoever who stole them.
I'm at the end of my training now. I'll ask Rachel to put me on your dad's delivery team so I can keep an eye out for him.
No, please, Noan...
Thank you for offering, but I think it's best that you stay out of this.
And that was the last time Noan ever saw Field.
Field left nothing in the book storage—except for his half-finished firefly toy and his notebook.

The notebook comes with an instruction sheet in it on how to put together the firefly toy. The rest of the notebook is full of Field's thoughts and sentences and lines that he's copied off the books he read.
The handwriting from the first half of the notebook is neat, and that's when Field was still writing about the changing seasons of nature—signs that he was still in a stable condition then.
The handwriting and content from the second half, however, are the exact opposite of what they are in the first half—with stains of blood here and there on the pages.
When Noan gets to the very last two pages, he has to read the words three times to finally understand what they say.

Params[1]: I'll turn to the darkness and wander in the nothingness.
You still expect my largesse. What can I offer you? Ceaseless, it is still darkness and void and—stop.
But I'd like only darkness, or to vanish into your daytime; I'd only like a void that never seizes your heart.
I travel alone—not only without you, but in darkness without other shadows.
Only myself, submerged by darkness, in that world wholly mine.

Params[3]: Noan puts down the notebook and looks around—but can't seem to see Field anywhere in the otherwise usually crowded lower-level car that now only has a handful of souls.
Unable to see any further and feeling helpless, Noan starts shouting out his friend's name—among people ready for bed.
Summer! Field!
For crying out loud, kid! Do you know what time it is?!
Not surprisingly at all, people don't hesitate to yell at him.
Sorry, but I'm just looking for my friend because he went missing.
He what? You sure he didn't head out with the Cargo Crew? They're supposed to head down to City 074 tonight and will be back in the morning.
The man sits up from his dirty mattress with a yawn.
He's about my age, and there is no way he'd have left with the Cargo Crew because he just isn't fit enough to do that.
Not fit enough... Wait, are you talking about Bancroft's son?
Yes, that's him. Have you...
Wouldn't say a thing even if I've seen him. We're damn fed up with all Bancroft's little drama and just can't wait to see him kicked off the train.
Ditto. Ain't it funny how shit happens to his team every single time?
Dude just shouldn't be a captain, period. None of his men listens to him, and their goods go missing whenever they're out on a mission.
I just want the guy gone ASAP so we can all have a good night's sleep.
You really think that's gonna put an end to the situation?
Excuse me?
There will be a second and third and more Bancrofts as long as the guards from the upper level keep their rules in place!
We could choose to sit around and watch them die, but you never know who it's gonna be next.
He has it coming.
But he was only just trying to save someone!
Leaking info and losing goods are what's considered wrong now according to the rules, but who's to say the rules are going to stay this way forever?
Remember that "we're all heroes or we're all zeroes" rule they just put into place in the Industrial Carriage?

The aristocrats would be more than happy to keep shipping someone off there that hampers the rest of the team, so long as people keep trying to single out the "bad apple"—or so Captain Rachel always says.
Are all the "bad apples" to blame for all our sufferings?
No, they're not—because as long as they can trade in "info" for resources, people will jump at the opportunity any day of the week.
See, we've twisted the rules against ourselves when the rules are what's wrong in the first place!
I'm not saying that I stand with these people, but the rules are what's wrong, and I sympathize with all the innocent people that get dragged through the mud.

Why are we turning our backs on Field when he's done nothing wrong and wants to bring about changes? We hate the aristocrats' guts for treating us the way they do, but aren't we doing the exact same thing?
Wow, shithead. Think you know everything, huh?
I like everything he said, though. Atta boy, son.
Captain Shauna?!
Thought I'd drop by when I heard all the buzz coming from down here. Don't worry, though. Rachel ain't around, and I won't tell her a thing.
Field went missing, Shauna.
Sure you've looked everywhere?
I went through all the places he'd usually go to, and his notebook is the only thing I found.
Noan hands the notebook over to Shauna. She quickly goes through it.
Let's look for him together. Kid might still be around.
But we can't let Bancroft stick around anymore!
Your sick wife, Rock's kids, and Jason's mom—these are just some of the people who are here that we should just kick off the train, and I can keep going if you want me to.
Oh yeah, just FYI, I know what they're all up to.
Y'all hate Bancroft's guts because he's been capitalizing on what y'all do, right?
Desperate times call for desperate measures, and I totally get that.
And y'all are damn right to say that he's got what's coming his way—but who are y'all to say you're any less guilty?
What do you mean?
Y'all let him handle the goods alone knowing that he'd lose them. Need I say more?
And boy, I would have told Rachel all these already had I heard about them earlier.
Rachel doesn't know any of these?
Like hell she would!
She's been doin' all these things to help make life better for us—while we're all busy here trying to help those scoundrels up there screw ourselves over.
Does seeing Bancroft screw up over and over again make life better for any of you?
Do they come down here and strangle someone you hate every time Bancroft loses his goods and snitches?
Shauna throws a punch at the wall with her smile still on her face.
Now, just answer me this—are you going to help look for Field or not?
Dead silence ensues—until someone from the Maintenance Crew speaks up.
I'll check out the security cameras over at the storage and send a few guys down the ventilation ducts. Those places ain't the easiest for kids to get back out once they're in there.
Thank you...!
And we need you to come with us, kid.
Sure!
Noan leaves the car with the man.
And what's it gonna be for the rest of you?
I'll look around.
...I'll go with you.
Should we double-check with Rachel to see if the kid is out with the team?
Right. I'll do that with my terminal.
Tsk...!
Stay here if you want, but tag along if you can lend us a hand.
Lucy, do us a favor and check out where you and the kids usually play hide-and-seek.
On it!

And with it, people start forming search teams. There are still people who are either unwilling to help or unable to help, but things are already looking a lot better than if Noan had to do it on his own.
This single event isn't going to erase all the hard feelings that are already there—but Noan can just feel that they've just made a dent in the tip of the iceberg.
...Field, where are you?
The boy calls out his friend's name as the sun begins to slowly show its face to the world for the day.
